comments.commentBody: You know Martin A-S is Canadian, right?  Celine is too, not from the Bronx like we are.

Yes, I think we all react that way. Which presents a conundrum. If a female boss, by virtue of her sex, will have a different emotional effect on her employees than a male boss when engaging in identical behavior, does this not unfairly disadvantage the female boss? But at the same time, the reaction is real, and a leader has to elicit the best performance from his or her subordinates.

It's here that I start to wonder just how far we can transcend our instinctual nature. At what point are we no longer dealing with culturally-based assumptions and dealing with basic human nature instead?

I continue to be haunted by an article about women at Harvard business school, executives who had to be taught to put their hands up -- literally -- and who seemed more interested in acquiring husbands than anything else. Part of me is screaming "get real."

I am reminded of Brooks and Applebee's when I see all this about what is necessary to understand other people.
http://crooksandliars.com/2008/06/03/memo-to-david-brooks-applebees-does...

Really? Who knows for sure? I'm thinking that her co-workers and subordinates may have a pretty good idea whether it was fair. Not handled with much respect? Exactly how was she disrespected? I've been through three senior executive firings and never, ever, has management come in and praised the firerees' past performance and commitment to the organization - but that's what they did for her! Last time I was fired was in 1985 and what I got was a message on my answering machine telling me not to come back...ever.

What gender diversity in management means is that women have the same opportunity to get fired for being obnoxious, incompetent or on the wrong side of a leadership battle just like men always have. And yeah, sometimes it's not fair. Welcome to the club.

It is the 'old boys club' and that will never change. No matter how good we are, how tough or how smart, they rule. Sad, but true.

Was she unfairly fired? Who knows for sure. But it was not handled with much respect. And that I have an issue with.

That sexism occurs, and I recognize and concur with your point about different perceptions of identical behavior by men and women -- doesn't mean that it occurred in this case. There are, after all, male leaders who have a wretched style of leadership -- I've had the misfortune to work under a couple of them. And problems of that kind were mentioned in the dismissal of Jill's predecessor.

The Pine Island glacier in west Antarctica only comprises about 5% of Antarctic ice. But most of it is 1-2 miles above sea level. Given a hundred thousand years of downhill glacial flow to polish its base, once this ice mass cuts loose, it will travel downhill more like an avalanche than a glacier.

While this ice volume will only raise the sea level by about 10 cm, its high speed entry into the southern Pacific will potentially trigger a major tsunami event.

Even the most climate-sensitive individuals like Al Gore or Dr. Krugman think that accelerated ice release will happen over decades. Anyone who has witnessed (or personally felt) an avalanche knows the immediacy of this falsehood.

Sometimes Mother Nature moves very, very fast.

Suggested reading: 'Above Evil, A Science Prediction Novel'. Available on Amazon.

My husband and I both work full-time, we have 3 kids, 6-yr old twins + an 8-yr old. For years we were in a terrible rut, getting home minutes before needing to feed the kids, and slapping together whatever “kid-friendly” food could be made quickly. The result: a rotation of pasta, eggs, fish sticks, hot dogs, etc. We needed a major change, and have been trying over the past year to change it up, but are still struggling. I cook most weekends, and my husband cooks most weekday dinners.  His day off is Mon., so he's been trying to plan and cook that day, but we still end up with pizza, pasta, or something equally uncreative several nights a week. We keep kosher and occasionally eat meat, but have been trying to transition to a more vegetarian diet. Even with planning and good intentions, we still end up getting into ruts and making the same recipes over and over again (especially if it's easy and the kids seem to like it).  We try to expose the kids to new foods, but when we deviate too far from stuff they are used it does not go well. One child is particularly picky and often will hardly eat dinner at all. We are determined to keep working on it, especially because we want to expose our kids to lots of different types of food and move them away from having such limited/picky diets. But we've got a long way to go and would love some creative ideas and external motivation to help us make progress towards our overall goals of healthier, more balanced, and more diverse eating.

India's Lok Sabha has 545 seats, 543 are elected, and 2 seats are reserved.  The 2 seats in the Lok Sabha (Lower House in India's Parliament) to be filled in through Appointment are reserved for the Anglo-Indian community.  This Community represented the children from British fathers with Indian (or colored!) mothers.  These Anglo Indian communities were mainly concentrated  in areas like Calcutta, Bangalore, Bombay, Pune, Jamshedpur -- areas which were centers of industries, military cantonments, and the railway.  This Community, unfortunately, thought and acted as if they were more British than the Britishers!  This Community alone supported and even raised funds to defend Gen. Dyer, the British Military Officer who ordered and killed hundreds of Indians attending a national rally for India's Independence in Jaliwanabagh, Punjab!  (The Jaliwana Bagh Massacre!) Anyway, the Constituent Assembly, which was chaired by Dr. Ambedkar (an alumni from the Columbia University, NY, Law School), and which worked for 3 years to write up the Indian Constitution (the Longest Constitution in the World), thought it prudent to reserve 2 seats for this Anglo-Indian community, and these 2 seats would be filled in by the Government after due consultation.  In the past, great individuals often were appointed to the Lok Sabha under these 2 reserved seats.

God has just helped the minorities in India. No longer will they be treated as tools for politics. No longer will they be looked on as vote banks. Religious minorities will now find that their religion is a private matter, they are free to practice what they wish, and the state will not incite people on the basis of their religion. Let's hope the uniform civil code is adopted as well. We need to put an end to government interference in religion. Every citizen will be the same regardless of their religion.
May God help people of religious minorities in India.
